title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Things to address

Difference between entailment and presupposition.
Conventional implicature versus the other inference types.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Entailment vs. presupposition
First pass:

Presuppositions encode background information, needed to make sense of some expression.

Express what must already be in the common ground (Stalnaker 1978).

Entailments encode information about what is said.

Express information, e.g., which is being added to the common ground.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
The negation test
Second pass:

Presuppositions project, whereas entailments do not.



Jo demonstrated that she’s good at Go. 
Jo loves that she’s good at Go.


Jo didn’t demonstrate that she’s good at Go. 
Jo doesn’t love that she’s good at Go.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
More!


Bo brought a dog to his place of work. 
Bo brought the dog to his place of work.


Bo didn’t bring a dog to his place of work. 
Bo didn’t bring the dog to his place of work.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
The question test


Did Jo demonstrate that she’s good at Go?
Does Jo love that she’s good at Go?


Did Jo bring a dog to his place of work? 
Did Jo bring the dog to his place of work?

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
The conditional test


If Jo demonstrated that she’s good at Go, she’ll have to join the Go league. 
If Jo loves that she’s good at Go, she’ll have to join the Go league.


If Bo brought a dog to his place of work, the boss will be mad. 
If Bo brought the dog to his place of work, the boss will be mad.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Families of sentences
These tests are known as family-of-sentence tests (Chierchia and McConnell-Ginet 1990).

Given a sentence \(S_{1}\), from which you can infer \(S_{2}\):

negate \(S_{1}\);
question \(S_{1}\);
put \(S_{1}\) into the antecedent of a conditional.



If \(S_{2}\) survives (i.e., projects), probably a presupposition.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Hey, wait a minute!
The hey, wait a minute test (von Fintel 2004).

Bo: You love that you’re good at Go.  Jo: Hey, wait a minute! I’m not good at Go!
Bo: You demonstrated that you’re good at Go!  Jo: #Hey, wait a minute! I’m not good at Go!  Jo: No, I didn’t!

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Hey, wait a minute!

Jo: You brought the dog to your place of work!  Bo: Hey, wait a minute! There isn’t a dog!

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Interim summary
Distinguishing entailments and presuppositions from conversational implicatures:

defeasibility/contradiction test


Distinguishing entailments from presuppositions:

family-of-sentence tests
“hey wait a minute” test

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Now you try it!

Mo forgot that he went to class.  ↝ Mo went to class.



Mo forgot to eat breakfast.  ↝ Mo didn’t eat breakfast.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Question

Why do presuppositions “project”?

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Disappearing presuppositions

If Bo has a dog, he brought the dog to his place of work.
If Jo is actually good at Go, she loves that she’s good at Go.



It’s not true that Bo has a dog and that he brought the dog to his place of work.
It’s not true that Jo is good at Go and that she loves that she’s good at Go.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Changing presuppositions

If Jo has any friends in Gainesville, she loves that she gets to see them.  ↝ If Jo has any friends in Gainesville, she gets to see them.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Conventional implicatures

The class is taught by Julian, who enjoys syntax.  ↝ Julian enjoys syntax.
The class isn’t taught by Julian, who enjoys syntax.  ↝ Julian enjoys syntax.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Can they disappear?

#If Julian enjoys syntax, then the class is taught by Julian, who enjoys syntax.

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
Summary
Distinguishing entailments/presuppositions from conv. implicatures:

defeasibility/contradiction test

Distinguishing entailments from presuppositions:

family-of-sentence tests
“hey wait a minute” test


Distinguishing presuppositions from conventional implicatures:

conventional implicatures always project (?)

title: Intro. to Semantics
text:
References




Chierchia, Gennaro, and Sally McConnell-Ginet. 1990. Meaning and Grammar: An Introduction to Semantics. Cambridge: MIT Press.


Stalnaker, Robert. 1978. “Assertion.” In Pragmatics, edited by Peter Cole, 9:315–32. New York: Academic Press.


von Fintel, Kai. 2004. “Would You Believe It? The King of France Is Back! (Presuppositions and Truth-Value Intuitions).” In Descriptions and Beyond, edited by Marga Reimer and Anne Bezuidenhout. New York: Oxford University Press.
